utterances: Do you get the sense that she understands the significance of her time at Parker?
No, she really doesn't.
Crystal moved to Birmingham not many years ago, so she don't know the history behind the racial relationship here in Birmingham especially and throughout Alabama.
The Civil Right movement that actually pretty much started here from Parker High School with many, many students going down to march with Dr. King back in the '60s and things of that nature.
She has heard about it and had read something about it as related in our history books and things of that nature, but I don't think she has seen the real culture.

Even though this community itself was involved in that process tremendously as related to the marching — the dogs being released and the fire hose and things of that nature, she had no real knowledge of that.
So that, probably from her standpoint, would you say, then, that was maybe a blessing for her to not have that to cloud her judgment?
Yeah.
Unidentified Boy #6: Aiyah!
Kick, kick, kick, follow this with your hand.
Kick, kick, hand - there you go.
Aiyah!
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""AUTUMN LEAVES"")
Right, right.
One of the things I heard her state earlier was that, you know, people just treat her just like she is a student.
Well, yes, that is true.
She is just another student here.

We do have some other white students who go here now, but she is actually the first one to graduate from this school in over 100 years, which is significant in itself because of the race relationship in this community itself, in this city, and things of that nature.
For many, many years, blacks were sort of put on the back burner as related to our white counterparts in a number of ways.
Let me interrupt you to ask this, Joe.
Sure.

Did you - because you're the principal, and because even though you had other white students there and have some there now, Crystal is the first to graduate - did you feel an obligation to provide her any sort of special accommodation?
No, at no time, because Crystal was a good fit.
She was a very normal child.
She was a good student and things of that nature - a solid citizen and things of that nature.
She's one of those kids who minded her own business.
Now, she had the same kind of problems with students that anybody else would have in the school, but she just stayed focused all four years she was here.
Now, let's flip the script, so to speak…
Sure.
…with regard to - we know how she was able to get through it sort of with a color blindness that worked to her advantage.
But how did the black students deal with her and her notoriety I guess would be one way of putting it now that she's graduated and become the first black and has gotten a great deal of attention?
Are there some hurt feelings…
No.
…some jealousies around any of that?
No, Crystal is family.
I mean, you know, some of the kids were really excited for her.
And some of them, who even was on other shows and things of that nature with her, the kids were very, very happy for her.
They make announcements throughout the school.
As a matter of fact we turned on television sets on the last day when she was on another national show and kids were all glued to the TV.
And, you know, you could hear the cheers and things of that nature and all the congratulatory things that was said about her
She fits in really well with the kids here because she had befriended some of these kids a couple of years before she got to Parker.
As a matter of fact, she went to a middle school here.
She went to two middle schools: Lincoln and also Washington.
And so she knew some of these kids from growing up in the neighborhood and having gone to middle school with them.
So it made the transition sort of easy.
So it was not a difficult process.
She was able to, you know, just be herself…
Mm-hmm.
…you know, which was just normal for her.
Mm-hmm.
So next year at this time, Joe Martin, at graduation you'll have white students again, presumably.
And it won't be such a big deal, will it?
No, it probably won't.
You know, as I stated to someone earlier, you know, I'm glad to see this happening here at this school because it is a school rich in tradition and history.
But it was long overdue, from my standpoint, as related to having taught here for 9 or 10 years prior to me becoming the principal.
I have seen some who have come on board only to leave and go to other schools and things of that nature.
But it was never for problem's sake.
It was always for socialization.
But Crystal didn't even seem to have that problem.
She kind of socialized with the kids at the prom, the football games, basketball games and things of that nature, so she fit right in with the group and they all took care of her, you know.
She needed a ride, she'd roll with them.
And if they needed a ride, they'd roll with her.
So it was never a big issue.
Well, congratulations to Crystal, congratulations to you, and congratulations to Parker High.
Thank you so much.
Joe Parker is the principal of A.H.
Parker High School in Birmingham, Alabama.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Alex Cohen.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Maybe the two of you have been together for years.
It was great at first, but now, well, it's getting a little old.
You miss the excitement, the novelty, that smell.
I'm talking, of course, of your love affair with your car.
If you're looking to trade it in, be careful.
Breaking up can be hard and expensive, and you might find yourself owing more on your car than its worth.
Here with more is DAY TO DAY's personal finance contributor Michelle Singletary.
Hi, Michelle.
Hi.
Okay.
I understand there's a special term for this.
Yes.
Well, if you break up and you still owe money on your car, you can be what's called upside down on the loan, meaning that you owe more than the car is worth.
According to Kelley Bluebook, about a quarter or more of car buyers are upside down on their loans, owing as much as $3,600 when they go to trade in the car.
Whoops.
So how do you avoid owing money?
Well, first of all, you keep the car.
Stay in the love affair.
You know, get new car smell and spray it in there.
You know, rejuvenate the love affair.
You don't want to trade-in the car when you owe a balance on the loan.
And then, many car owners are rolling that balance into the new loan.
Or they take a cash rebate.
And instead of, you know, reducing the price of the car they're paying on, they have to use their cash rebate to make up for the difference in the loan that they owe.
Well, the standard loan is, what, five years for a car?
Now the average car loan is five years or 60 months.
And now there are car loans as long as six, seven and even eight years.
So how do you avoid that?
How do you avoid getting into such a long-term loan where you're paying and paying and paying and it never ends?
There are days I wish I was teaching something more benign.
But whether adults want to see it or not, childhood is an aggressive time.
Kids live in the world of the playground.
Pushing and pushing back is the big part of it.
I know there is something important these kids get out of learning how to fight.
Some of the kids are scared.
Some of them are scarily fearless.
Mia is agile.
Her hair is pulled back from her face in perfect cornrows, each ending in a beautiful ringlet.
She's nine, but she's the size of a seven-year-old.
I'm small and I don't like to tell people what I weigh that much, like, I'm not really excited about it.
But I don't mind telling some people how much I weigh.
Fifty pounds.
Fifty pounds.
But even though she's that little, I've put her in the adult fighting class because she's so focused and so good.
She sometimes spars with men who weigh 200 pounds.
She'll kick their knees, climb on their backs, get them to the ground where size isn't as much of a factor.
The adults don't baby her, but they don't intimidate her either.
I'm careful to keep that balance.
It felt really good to know that I can be respected.
She's learning how to use her hands like snakes and wrap up the guys' throats.
And it's been working on them.
Today, when a bigger boy comes at her with charging fist, a flicker of concern crosses her face.
I can tell it's not easy for her.
There's a moment when she freezes.
But she doesn't back up or let up.
Her arms are in ready position and she manages to parry most of his punches.
When I call time, she's damped with sweat and we catch eyes.
I can tell she knows that small isn't the same as powerless.
